greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Square array A(row,col) read by downwards antidiagonals: A(1,1) = 1, A(row,1) = A055938(row-1), and for col > 1, A(row,col) = A005187(1+A(row,col-1)).
comment: The array is read by antidiagonals: A(1,1), A(1,2), A(2,1), A(1,3), A(2,2), A(3,1), etc.

Provided that I understand Kimberling's terminology correctly, this array is the dispersion of sequence b(n) = A005187(n+1), for n>=1: A005187[2..] = [3, 4, 7, 8, 10, 11, ...]. The left column is the complement of that sequence, which is {1} followed by A055938. - _Antti Karttunen_, Apr 17 2015
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10440; the first 144 antidiagonals of array
Clark Kimberling, Interspersions and Dispersions, Proceedings of the American Mathematical Society, 117 (1993) 313-321.
Index entries for sequences that are permutations of the natural numbers
